Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research- SusChEM: Graded Interpenetrating Polymer Membranes Based on Sustainable Materials for Selective Removal of Organics from Water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512225/1510475
Alcantar/Cardena-Valencia
U of S. Florida/SRI

The collaborative team proposes to develop and investigate the performance of membranes based on natural, sustainable materials to remove organic contaminants from water. The ultimate goal of this project is to create novel membranes based on materials that have the ability to attract water pollutants and are renewable, biodegradable, and can be obtained via sustainable agriculture. A high percentage of the network forming these novel membranes will come from natural sugars and waxes. These compounds will be extracted from cactus mucilage, the gooey part of cacti. The separation process will invoke a similar function that cactus plants use to transport water to survive in arid environments to mimic the separation process of pollutants from water.

The proposed work focuses on the application of fundamental research of sustainable and natural materials capable of removing harmful organic chemicals from water. Although poly dimethyl siloxane (PDMS) membranes are readily-used in organic separations due to their hydrophobic nature and permeability to gases and organics, separation of higher molecular weight organics-semi-VOCs and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs)-remains challenging due to slow time-constants and selectivity. This project will invoke biomimicry to comparatively evaluate the use of polysaccharides from mucilage to emulate nutrient pathways in cacti. The polysaccharides will be cross-linked in PDMS networks and also in cutin waxes (materials that form the cactus skin). Since cutin waxes are extremely hydrophobic, this work potentially could establish that PDMS membranes will be replaced for more sustainable materials, which will be of high impact in the field.

Students working on this project will be trained to apply creative engineering perspectives to solving chemical and industrial challenges in problems intrinsically related to environmental assessments and water quality. The inclusion of undergraduate students will be achieved via an undergraduate research exchange internship between USF and SRI. In addition, high school students will be exposed to this project; the PIs will develop a new chemical laboratory lesson plan for a local high school in St. Petersburg, Florida.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to create new materials that could enhance the recovery of trace organic compounds and crude oils using novel cross-linked interpenetrating polymer networks and gradient interpenetrating polymer membranes made from cactus mucilage. We focused our work on studying the performance of these polymers according to their likeness to water. These polymeric networks were created from extracts of natural materials and characterized by physically and chemically for their implementation as pollutant separation systems. We accomplished this goal by creating new materials in the form of fibers, beads, coatings, and as powders. We have been able to construct membranes of such materials by using electrophoresis.  This research led to understand how structure relates to performance and how to optimize their performance by modifying structure.

Intellectual Merit:

We achieved the following: First, to the best of our knowledge, the materials we created are novel and have only been created in our lab. Second, the carbon footprint of robust membranes from natural polysaccharides is minimal compared to existing membranes used in water purification. Third, this proposed research has transformed the field of new membranes to clean organic compounds and high molecular hydrocarbons from water-based, non-toxic extracts from the Opuntia ficus-indica plant. Our polymers can perform in various chemical environments and diverse applications. We create coating materials and systems for separation columns and powders that can be added to water as natural dispersants. Fourth, the new natural polysaccharide-based membranes were characterized physically and chemically. Fifth, the synthesis and implementation processes were optimized along with the term of the research. For instance, for materials that could be implemented as membranes, the highest separation efficiencies were tight to the networks' cross-linking capacity. 

 Broader Impacts:

We trained and advised 5 undergraduate and 7 graduate students. This project allowed us to file for 12 inventiona disclosuresand we were granted 9 patents of them during the duration of this project. The dissemination of the project was vast since more than 30 presentations and products were published or distributed during the time that this project was funded. The information obtained also led to new discoveries and applications of interprenetrating networks made of cactus related to biomedical engineering, Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease and Colloids and Interfaces.

Modified by: Norma Alcantar

This research led to understand how structure relates to performance and how to optimize their performance by modifying structure. Our polymers can perform in various chemical environments and diverse applications. We create coating materials and systems for separation columns and powders that can be added to water as natural dispersants.
